subject: Re: [junit] Which tests to write?
msgSnippet: ... There s a way the method can break: e.g. if the merge sort implementation does not work with collections under a certain size (precondition) and the
messageBody:
> Suppose you wrote the sort methods. That means that they have tests,
> and damn good ones. As a result, a method like this can't break on its
> own:
>
> if myCollection.size < 20
> myCollection.sortWith(SortAlgorithms.bubbleSort)
> else if myCollection.size < 100
> myCollection.sortWith(SortAlgorithms.quickSort)
> else
> myCollection.sortWith(SortAlgorithms.mergeSort)
> end

There's a way the method can break: e.g. if the merge sort implementation
does not work with collections under a certain size (precondition) and the
threshold in the sort method was chosen incorrectly. Or the changed
implementation of merge sort changed the threshold. The underlying pre- and
postconditions can change without noticing as long as they are not
formalized and proven to hold.

But probably you are right and the sort example is not as good as I thought
in the beginning. So I declare myself defeated until I come up with an
example that makes sense as is and not only when considered in an abstract
way.

Johannes
